A silver pendant depicting the Darkmoon and a sword, the crest of the Darkmoon Knights, the original Blue Sentinels.
Increases FP recovery by 13 whilst worn.
Enables the collection of Proof of a Concord Kept from enemies.
When a member of the Way of Blue faces a dark spirit, the Blades of the Darkmoon, by an ancient accord, help to root out the invader.

Ancient medallion depicting the crest of a wolf. Symbolizes the pact with the Old Wolf of Farron.
Reduces weapon stamina consumption by 10% whilst worn.
Enables the collection of Wolf's Blood Swordgrass from enemies.
The Watchdogs ensure that the warriors sleep in serenity, by taking the form of loyal spirits and hunting down those who would trespass the woods of Farron.

An ancient talisman depicting a holy symbol bestowed upon the Warriors of Sunlight.
Boosts Lightning damage by 5% whilst worn.
Enables the collection of Sunlight Medal from enemies.
Warriors of Sunlight are brilliantly beaming co-operators who place their golden signatures to help those in need, for it is their duty to deliver a great conquest to their summoner.

A malformed vertebra found by the mad, with a queer symbol on its inside, proof of the shackles of the Gods.
Increases Physical damage by 5% whilst worn.
Enables the collection of Vertebra Shackle from enemies.
The mound-makers wish only to add to their mounds, becoming mad spirits whether summoned as co-operators or invaders. They are blithe to those around them, for in their minds, any kill might lead to another shackle.

A ring for warriors keen on heavy accoutrements. Increases maximum equip load by 20%.
This ring was named after Havel the Rock, the battlefield compatriot of Gwyn, the First Lord.
The art of war has been a constant since ages past, and those who would follow in Havel's footsteps are no fewer now than in his own day.

This mystical ring was created in a sacrificial rite of Velka, the Goddess of Sin.
Its wearer will lose nothing upon death, but the ring itself breaks.
A sacrifice is only worth as much as the life it spares.

Its wearer will lose nothing upon death, and will be freed from any curse whatsoever, but the ring itself breaks.
A sacrifice is only worth as much as the life it spares.

Ring given in Vinheim, home of sorcery, when newly ordained as a sorcerer.
Periodically summons homing soulmasses every 15 seconds.
Apropos to the Dragon School, the seal depicts an everlasting dragon. A young dragon presages the great length of the journey to mastery.

Ring said to be chiselled from the bone of a flame salamander by blighted Pyromancers living in the Great Swamp.
Periodically emit pillars of flame every 30 seconds.
It is believed that salamanders are the descendants of demons, born of the Chaos Flame, from which Pyromancy is also said to have originated.

A malformed ring given to knights of Carim.
Periodically emit damaging force wave every 15 seconds.
Morne served the goddess Caitha and later became an apostle of the Archbishop. They labored together to provide comfort to the suffering.

A malformed ring left by Aldrich, Saint of the Deep.
Recovers HP from backstabs and ripostes, restoring 100 HP.
Aldrich, infamous for his appetite for flesh, apparently had the desire to share with others his joy of imbibing the final shudders of life while luxuriating in his victim's screams.

An old ring with a seal depicting a horse's hoof.
Enables simple kicking. Replaces Guard action with shield or weapon. Boosts stamina drain by 100% when kicking.
Unbreakable Patches adored this ring and the feeling that it gave it him when he kicked his marks into the depths of treacherous traps, but suffered no shortage of ridicule from his associates for relying so heavily on the tired old trick. But who is the sorrier? The horse who knows only to kick, or the fool who approaches the old beast without thought?

Ring worn by warriors of the sand kingdom, Carthus.
Shifts evasion class downwards and obscures rolling, but increases evasive stamina costs by 50%.
The sword technique of Carthus allows for fluid movement with a curved sword. Masters of the technique are said to dazzle their opponents by moving as weightlessly as a grain of sand.

A divine ring granted to the Darkmoon Gwyndolin in his youth.
Causes males to perform female actions, and vice-versa.
Gwyndolin was raised like a daughter through the aura of the moon, and was said to behave like a sullen brooding goddess.

Bewitched ring that Pontiff Sulyvahn bestowed upon his knights.
Recovers HP with successive attacks, restoring 5% HP per attack once triggered.
Knights who peer into the black orb are lured into battles of death, transformed into frenzied beasts. No wonder the Pontiff only provides these rings to those dispatched to foreign lands.

Ring of Oceiros, former king of Lothric.
Increases max FP by 10%.
In his later years, Oceiros became fascinated with dragons. After going mad, he was more commonly known as the Consumed King. Many assassins were dispatched to his domain, but none returned.
The Consumed King ascribed his resilience to the divine protection of the dragon scale.

The seal of an ancient order. It bares an uncanny resemblance to that of a wolf.
Whilst below 50%, ironskin is applied to the wearer.
Ironskin boosts Physical absorption by 20%, reduces elemental absorptions by 20%, prevents staggering and increases attack deflection by 65.
It is said that members of this ancient order were unmovable in battle, standing resolute no matter the foe.
